one_paragraph_summary: During this admission, a middle-aged woman with advanced AIDS and ESRD on hemodialysis presented with three days of worsening left groin pain, warmth, swelling, and a "hard bump" at her left femoral tunneled dialysis catheter, with subjective fevers and chills but initially stable vital signs. Examination showed a very tender, warm indurated area near the catheter, and initial labs revealed chronic anemia (Hgb ~8 g/dL), leukopenia (WBC ~3–4 K/uL), and ESRD-range creatinine with low phosphate and potassium. She had already received ceftazidime and vancomycin at dialysis. The left femoral tunneled catheter was removed, and catheter tip and wound cultures grew MRSA; one blood culture also grew MRSA, while subsequent surveillance blood cultures remained negative, confirming MRSA catheter infection with bacteremia. She was treated with IV vancomycin dosed after hemodialysis, with levels monitored and a planned three-week course. After a line holiday, a right common femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter was placed, but TEE showed the catheter traversing a small secundum ASD into the left atrium with a small mobile echodensity on the tip consistent with thrombus; she was anticoagulated with a heparin infusion for 48 hours, after which repeat TEE showed resolution of the mass, and the catheter was exchanged for a shorter line with the tip in the upper IVC. She developed antibiotic-associated C. difficile colitis confirmed by positive stool PCR and was treated with a 14-day course of oral metronidazole. Nephrology managed her ESRD, holding sevelamer for hypophosphatemia while continuing cinacalcet, nephrocaps, epoetin, and doxercalciferol with dialysis. Given her very low CD4 count and high viral load, she was restarted on ART (abacavir, atazanavir/ritonavir, emtricitabine) while continuing TMP-SMX and azithromycin prophylaxis. Her paroxysmal atrial fibrillation remained in sinus rhythm; long-term anticoagulation was recommended but deferred due to adherence concerns, and she continued aspirin alone. By discharge she was afebrile, hemodynamically stable, with a clean right femoral catheter site, improving diarrhea, and stable chronic cytopenias, and she was discharged home with services to continue hemodialysis, post-dialysis vancomycin, metronidazole, and ART.

problem_list.problem: MRSA femoral catheter infection and MRSA bacteremia
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Presented with left groin pain, warmth, swelling, and induration at the left femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter site; catheter tip and wound cultures grew MRSA, and one blood culture grew MRSA, confirming catheter-related bloodstream infection. The infected left femoral catheter was removed, and she received IV vancomycin (after initial ceftazidime and gentamicin) with high early troughs requiring monitoring. Surveillance blood cultures after catheter removal showed no further growth. After a three-day line holiday, a new tunneled catheter was placed, and she was discharged to complete a three-week course of vancomycin dosed after hemodialysis.

problem_list.problem: Femoral catheter malposition across atrial septal defect with suspected thrombus
problem_list.status_at_discharge: After placement of a right common femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter, TEE revealed a small secundum ASD with the catheter coursing from the IVC across the defect into the left atrium and a small mobile echodensity on the catheter tip consistent with thrombus. She was anticoagulated with an IV heparin infusion for approximately 48 hours, during which PTTs were markedly elevated, and repeat TEE showed resolution of the mass. The catheter was then exchanged for a shorter tunneled catheter with the tip positioned in the upper IVC. Long-term systemic anticoagulation was recommended but not initiated due to adherence concerns and patient preference; she remained on aspirin alone.

Developed copious watery bowel movements approximately 24 hours after broad-spectrum antibiotics for catheter infection. Stool PCR was positive for toxigenic C. difficile. She was treated with oral metronidazole 500 mg three times daily for a planned 14-day course, with improvement in diarrhea by discharge and instructions to complete the course at home.

Has ESRD, anuric, on chronic hemodialysis. Her infected left femoral tunneled catheter was removed, and after a line holiday she underwent placement of a right common femoral tunneled catheter, later exchanged for a shorter catheter with the tip in the upper IVC. She continued thrice-weekly hemodialysis during admission with management of anemia (epoetin), secondary hyperparathyroidism (cinacalcet, IV doxercalciferol), and mineral bone disease (nephrocaps; sevelamer held due to hypophosphatemia). At discharge she remained dialysis-dependent with a functioning right femoral tunneled catheter and plans to continue outpatient hemodialysis and post-dialysis vancomycin.

problem_list.problem: Advanced HIV/AIDS with restart of antiretroviral therapy
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Has longstanding HIV/AIDS with very low CD4 count and high viral load prior to admission, previously off HAART but on TMP-SMX and azithromycin prophylaxis. During this hospitalization, after discussion with her HIV specialist and review of goals of care, she was restarted on ART with abacavir, atazanavir boosted with ritonavir, and emtricitabine (dosed after hemodialysis on specific days), while continuing TMP-SMX DS three times weekly and azithromycin 1200 mg weekly. She was discharged on this regimen with outpatient HIV follow-up arranged.

problem_list.problem: Chronic cytopenias (anemia and leukopenia) in the setting of HIV and ESRD
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Throughout admission she had chronic normo- to mildly macrocytic anemia (Hgb 7.1–8.5 g/dL, Hct low- to mid-20s) and leukopenia (WBC 2.3–3.6 K/uL) with normal platelet counts. Coagulation parameters (PT/INR) were normal aside from therapeutic PTT elevations on heparin. She received epoetin with dialysis but no transfusions are documented in the available data. At discharge, her hemoglobin remained around 7.7 g/dL and WBC 3.4 K/uL, stable for her baseline.

Known history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation; she remained in sinus rhythm during this admission. Cardiology recommended long-term systemic anticoagulation and beta-blocker therapy, but due to concerns about adherence and patient preference, warfarin was not started. She continued aspirin 325 mg daily for stroke prophylaxis.

problem_list.problem: Right V1 post-herpetic neuralgia and chronic pain
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Has chronic right V1 distribution post-herpetic neuralgia and headache with facial scarring and decreased vision in the right eye. During this admission her neuralgia was described as stable, and she continued low-dose duloxetine three times weekly after hemodialysis, along with acetaminophen and PRN hydromorphone for pain. No new neuropathic agents were added.

She has a history of depressed mood without documented active suicidal ideation during this stay. Her mood was described as stable. No new antidepressant was started specifically for depression, though duloxetine was continued primarily for neuropathic pain and may provide mood benefit. Outpatient psychiatric follow-up was recommended.

key_tests_and_results.test: Initial laboratory evaluation on admission (CBC, BMP, coagulation, electrolytes)
key_tests_and_results.result: On admission, labs showed anemia and leukopenia with Hgb about 8.3 g/dL, Hct ~26%, WBC ~4.0 K/uL, MCV ~99 fL, platelets in the normal range, creatinine 2.7 mg/dL, BUN 7 mg/dL, sodium 142 mEq/L, potassium 3.1 mEq/L, chloride 104 mEq/L, bicarbonate 27 mEq/L, anion gap 14, calcium 8.9 mg/dL, phosphate 1.5 mg/dL, magnesium 1.8 mg/dL, and normal PT/INR and PTT.

Ultrasound of the left lower extremity showed suboptimal evaluation of the left common femoral and proximal superficial femoral veins due to pain limiting compression, but otherwise no evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the left lower extremity; calf veins were not well seen.

key_tests_and_results.test: Catheter tip and wound cultures from left femoral HD catheter
key_tests_and_results.result: Catheter tip and wound cultures from the left femoral hemodialysis catheter site grew oxacillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), with susceptibilities showing resistance to oxacillin, clindamycin, erythromycin, and levofloxacin, and susceptibility to vancomycin, gentamicin, rifampin, tetracycline, and TMP-SMX.

One blood culture grew MRSA, confirming bacteremia, while multiple subsequent blood cultures drawn on later days showed no growth, indicating clearance of bacteremia after catheter removal and antibiotic therapy.

Initial TEE demonstrated a small secundum atrial septal defect with the right femoral tunneled HD catheter coursing from the IVC across the defect into the left atrium and a small mobile echodensity on the catheter tip consistent with thrombus; there was no evidence of valvular vegetations and biventricular systolic function was normal. A repeat TEE 48 hours later, after heparin anticoagulation, showed the catheter still traversing the ASD but no residual thrombus on the catheter tip.

key_tests_and_results.test: Right common femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter placement and exchange imaging
key_tests_and_results.result: Interventional radiology placed a 50-cm right common femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter with the tip in the right atrium, later exchanged for a shorter 36-cm dual-lumen catheter via the same tract, with the final catheter tip positioned in the upper IVC and ready for use.
Stool testing by DNA amplification assay was positive for toxigenic Clostridium difficile, confirming C. difficile colitis.

Serum vancomycin levels were elevated early in the course (e.g., 33.6 µg/mL and 32.8 µg/mL), prompting careful dosing adjustments around hemodialysis; later levels decreased toward the therapeutic range (e.g., 20.9 µg/mL).

On the morning of discharge, labs showed WBC 3.4 K/uL, Hgb 7.7 g/dL, Hct 24.0%, platelets 244 K/uL, creatinine 5.7 mg/dL, BUN 35 mg/dL, sodium 138 mEq/L, potassium 4.0 mEq/L, chloride 99 mEq/L, bicarbonate 27 mEq/L, anion gap 16, calcium 8.7 mg/dL, phosphate 3.4 mg/dL, and magnesium 1.7 mg/dL.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Removal of infected left femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter
treatments_and_meds.details: Due to severe pain, warmth, swelling, and purulent drainage at the left femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter site, interventional radiology removed the tunneled catheter under sterile conditions. The catheter tip was sent for culture, which grew MRSA. This source control step was performed after initial antibiotics and before placement of a new tunneled catheter.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Placement and subsequent exchange of right common femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter
treatments_and_meds.details: After a line holiday, a 50-cm right common femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter was placed under ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance, with the tip in the right atrium and ready for use. Following TEE findings of the catheter traversing a small ASD into the left atrium with suspected thrombus, the catheter was later exchanged via the same tract for a shorter 36-cm dual-lumen catheter, with the tip repositioned in the upper IVC to avoid the defect.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Intravenous vancomycin for MRSA catheter infection and bacteremia
treatments_and_meds.details: She received IV vancomycin for MRSA catheter infection and bacteremia, initially after ceftazidime and gentamicin given at the dialysis unit. Vancomycin dosing was coordinated with hemodialysis sessions, with early trough levels elevated (e.g., 33.6 and 32.8 µg/mL), prompting careful monitoring and adjustment. She was discharged to complete a total three-week course of vancomycin dosed after outpatient hemodialysis sessions.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Systemic anticoagulation with heparin for catheter-associated thrombus across ASD
treatments_and_meds.details: After TEE showed the right femoral tunneled HD catheter traversing a small secundum ASD into the left atrium with a small mobile echodensity on the catheter tip consistent with thrombus, she was anticoagulated with an IV heparin infusion. PTT values became markedly elevated (up to 150 seconds), and after approximately 48 hours a repeat TEE showed resolution of the mass. The catheter was then exchanged for a shorter line. Long-term warfarin was recommended but not started; she continued aspirin only.

She continued thrice-weekly hemodialysis throughout the admission, with adjustments around catheter removal and re-placement. ESRD management included epoetin alfa for anemia, cinacalcet and IV doxercalciferol for secondary hyperparathyroidism, nephrocaps for vitamin supplementation, and temporary holding of sevelamer due to hypophosphatemia. Dialysis sessions were also used to coordinate vancomycin dosing and heparin dwell for catheter maintenance.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Treatment of C. difficile colitis with oral metronidazole
treatments_and_meds.details: Following onset of copious watery diarrhea and a positive stool PCR for toxigenic C. difficile, she was treated with oral metronidazole 500 mg three times daily for a planned 14-day course. An earlier brief course of oral vancomycin was discontinued. Her diarrhea improved by discharge, and she was instructed to complete the metronidazole course at home.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Restart of antiretroviral therapy and continuation of opportunistic infection prophylaxis
treatments_and_meds.details: Given her advanced AIDS with CD4 22 and high viral load, she was restarted on ART after discussion with her HIV specialist: abacavir 600 mg daily, atazanavir 300 mg daily boosted with ritonavir 100 mg daily, and emtricitabine 200 mg twice weekly after hemodialysis on specified days. She continued Pneumocystis prophylaxis with TMP-SMX DS three times weekly and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin 1200 mg weekly. Medication teaching and outpatient HIV follow-up were arranged.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Pain management and neuropathic pain therapy
treatments_and_meds.details: Her severe groin pain from the infected catheter and subsequent procedures was managed with IV and oral hydromorphone as needed, along with acetaminophen. Chronic right V1 post-herpetic neuralgia and headache were managed with continuation of low-dose duloxetine three times weekly after hemodialysis. Topical clobetasol and oral hydroxyzine were used for diffuse pruritus related to chronic skin disease and ESRD.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Management of atrial fibrillation and stroke prophylaxis
treatments_and_meds.details: She has paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and remained in sinus rhythm during this admission. Cardiology recommended long-term systemic anticoagulation and beta-blocker therapy, but due to concerns about adherence and patient preference, warfarin was not initiated. She continued aspirin 325 mg daily for stroke prophylaxis.

disposition.discharge_location: Home with home health services and outpatient hemodialysis
